intro: Cerinthopsis kurdica, commonly known as the Kurdish cerinthopsis, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Kurdistan. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone soils and thrives in temperate climates. Its botanical features include a slender stem and white to pale yellow flowers that bloom in early summer. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and potentially endangered species.
